text: High performance (think analysis/processing with 20 GB's + of data) backend code (whether webapp or desktop-GUI/CLI-based-app), what language do you guys recommend: Julia, C++,  Go, Rust?

elements.text: High performance (think analysis/processing with 20 GB's + of data) backend code (whether webapp or desktop-GUI/CLI-based-app), what language do you guys recommend: Julia, C++,  Go, Rust?

elements.text: Would your machine have 32GB of RAM?

elements.text: And maybe an Nvidia GPU? I’m going to try this in my PC soonish:

text:
If its a cloud based app, it shouldn't matter to much
If its a distributed desktop app, then most consumers won't have 32Gbs (standard is 16GB i think?)

Really looking for an all in one solution

elements.text:
If its a cloud based app, it shouldn't matter to much

text: Dask is more for data analysis, im thinking about softwares like CAD, Premier, Geneious. Think GUI's/CLI-options, customizable to user selection.

elements.text: Dask is more for data analysis, im thinking about softwares like CAD, Premier, Geneious. Think GUI's/CLI-options, customizable to user selection.

text: I’m not fully grasping what your need is.

elements.text: I’m not fully grasping what your need is.

text: Whats a good backend language for high preformance commercial software, Julia, C++, Go, Rust?.

elements.text: Whats a good backend language for high preformance commercial software, Julia, C++, Go, Rust?.

text: Anything would work fine?

elements.text: Anything would work fine?

text: Native user interfaces were problematic across Windows+MacOS when I thought about that many years ago. Now that I re-think it, maybe NodeJS, i.e. <https://www.electronjs.org>

attachments.title: Electron | Build cross-platform desktop apps with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS.
attachments.text: Build cross-platform desktop apps with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS.

elements.text: Native user interfaces were problematic across Windows+MacOS when I thought about that many years ago. Now that I re-think it, maybe NodeJS, i.e.

text: I don’t really know Electron, but the apps it lists are quite well done.

elements.text: I don’t really know Electron, but the apps it lists are quite well done.

text: Electron is usually used for the front end, not backend?

elements.text: Electron is usually used for the front end, not backend?

text: Yes, the backend doing analysis could be anything I guess. Julia maybe? :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Yes, the backend doing analysis could be anything I guess. Julia maybe?

text: I wonder if anyone has created a desktop app with Electron front-end and Julia backend.

elements.text: I wonder if anyone has created a desktop app with Electron front-end and Julia backend.

text:
The reason why Im asking is that there is more to backend than just language.

Sometimes a language is more suited for backend due to ecosystem, better memory management, or cross-OS-development/deploy

elements.text:
The reason why Im asking is that there is more to backend than just language.

Sometimes a language is more suited for backend due to ecosystem, better memory management, or cross-OS-development/deploy

text: Julia gets the job done and is fast but is it mature enough to be backend?

elements.text: Julia gets the job done and is fast but is it mature enough to be backend?

text: That is a good question. It’s probably risky?

elements.text: That is a good question. It’s probably risky?

text: For MacOS you probably could do all of it with Swift? It just doesn’t help at all with Windows.

elements.text: For MacOS you probably could do all of it with Swift? It just doesn’t help at all with Windows.

text: I could use swift but, I've never seen anyone use Swift for high preformance computing. Also as you said its MacOS only

elements.text: I could use swift but, I've never seen anyone use Swift for high preformance computing. Also as you said its MacOS only

text: why would you need a a more complicated gui than Tk for numerical computing?

elements.text: why would you need a a more complicated gui than Tk for numerical computing?

text: Swift can do Tensorflow, but that might not be what you mean by HPC. And as noted it’s Mac mostly-only. <https://www.tensorflow.org/swift>

attachments.title: Swift for TensorFlow
attachments.text: Swift for TensorFlow is a next generation system for deep learning and differentiable computing.

elements.text: Swift can do Tensorflow, but that might not be what you mean by HPC. And as noted it’s Mac mostly-only.

text: I declare mostly-only an English word. :joy:

elements.text: I declare mostly-only an English word.

text: The GUI part of Swift is Apple property, not open source, I meant.

elements.text: The GUI part of Swift is Apple property, not open source, I meant.

text: I can tell you from experience that "high-performance" being a requirement from a language is not a useful metric. If you need to do data analysis do it in Julia or Python-- those are the best languages for general data analysis. It will be a long time (longer with Julia :wink:) before you find that you're pushing the boundaries of what you can do in the language on your problem so hard that you need to use something else.

elements.text: I can tell you from experience that "high-performance" being a requirement from a language is not a useful metric. If you need to do data analysis do it in Julia or Python-- those are the best languages for general data analysis. It will be a long time (longer with Julia
) before you find that you're pushing the boundaries of what you can do in the language on your problem so hard that you need to use something else.
